verses.text: Jesus departed from there and went to His hometown, and His disciples followed Him.
verses.comment: Jesus returns to Nazareth, highlighting the pattern of prophetic rejection in one's own hometown. See Isaiah 61:1 where the Messiah comes to His own people.

verses.text: When the Sabbath came, He began to teach in the synagogue, and many who heard Him were astonished, saying, 'Where did this man learn these things? What is this wisdom that has been given to Him? And how are such mighty works done by His hands?'
verses.comment: Jesus teaches with authority and performs miracles, alluding to wisdom from above. See Isaiah 11:2. The people's astonishment shows His unique authority.

verses.text: Is this not the carpenter, the son of Mary and brother of James, Joses, Judas, and Simon? Are not His sisters here with us?' So they took offense at Him.
verses.comment: Referring to Jesus as 'the carpenter' and 'son of Mary' demonstrates His humble human origins. The mention of brothers and sisters reflects the Jewish custom of using these terms for close relatives, not always blood siblings (cf. Genesis 13:8, where 'brother' means 'relative').

verses.text: Jesus said to them, 'A prophet is not without honor, except in his own town, and among his relatives, and in his own household.'
verses.comment: Jesus identifies Himself as a prophet, referencing the frequent rejection of prophets by their own people (see 2 Chronicles 36:16).

verses.text: He could not do any mighty work there, except that He laid His hands on a few sick people and healed them.
verses.comment: Unbelief limited the manifestation of miracles, revealing the importance of faith in receiving grace, a recurring biblical theme (see Hebrews 11:6). Yet, Jesus still heals, underscoring God's mercy.

verses.text: And He was amazed at their lack of faith. Then He went around the surrounding villages teaching.
verses.comment: Jesus is astonished at unbelief. The response: Jesus continues His mission — He does not abandon the work even when rejected, showing perseverance in ministry.

verses.text: He called the twelve and began to send them out two by two, giving them authority over unclean spirits.
verses.comment: Jesus delegates authority to His apostles, establishing an order of leadership for the mission. The pattern of sending in pairs hints at the importance of unity and witness (see Deuteronomy 17:6; Ecclesiastes 4:9-12).

verses.text: He instructed them to take nothing for the journey except a staff—no bread, no bag, no money in their belts.
verses.comment: The apostles are to rely completely on God's providence. The simplicity of their lifestyle is a sign of total trust (cf. Exodus 12:11 for staff usage).

verses.text: They were to wear sandals, but not to put on two tunics.
verses.comment: Minimal provisions promote dependency on hospitality and spiritual solidarity. This foreshadows the apostolic mode of living — itinerant and trusting God entirely.

verses.text: He said to them, 'Wherever you enter a house, stay there until you leave that place.'
verses.comment: The apostles are to accept the first hospitality offered, showing contentment and avoiding favoritism. This practice protects both the preacher and the hearers (see 1 Corinthians 9:4).

verses.text: 'If any place will not welcome you or listen to you, shake the dust off your feet as a testimony against them when you leave.'
verses.comment: Shaking the dust is an act of judgment symbolizing separation from those who refuse the message (cf. Nehemiah 5:13; Acts 13:51).

verses.text: So they went out and proclaimed that people should repent.
verses.comment: Repentance is foundational to the gospel message, recalling the prophetic tradition (see Ezekiel 18:30).

verses.text: They cast out many demons and anointed with oil many who were sick and healed them.
verses.comment: Anointing with oil is a visible sign of healing and blessing still found in the apostolic community (cf. James 5:14).

verses.text: King Herod heard about this, for Jesus' name had become well known. People were saying, 'John the Baptist has been raised from the dead! That is why miraculous powers are at work in Him.'
verses.comment: Rumors about the identity of Jesus spread. The association with John the Baptist highlights prophetic succession and preparation for the Messiah.

verses.text: Others said, 'He is Elijah.' And still others said, 'He is a prophet, like one of the prophets of old.'
verses.comment: The expectation of Elijah's return stems from Malachi 4:5. Jesus is identified with the tradition of great prophets, yet He will be shown greater.

verses.text: But when Herod heard about it, he said, 'John, the man I beheaded, has been raised!'
verses.comment: Herod's guilty conscience reveals belief in resurrection and judgment. His words reflect a superstitious fear and a foreshadowing of Jesus' resurrection.

verses.text: For Herod himself had given orders to arrest John, bound him in prison for the sake of Herodias, his brother Philip’s wife, whom he had married.
verses.comment: Unlawful marriage is criticized by John the Baptist, a call to repentance which leads to his imprisonment, reminiscent of prophets unjustly treated (cf. Jeremiah 38:6).

verses.text: For John had been telling Herod, 'It is not lawful for you to have your brother’s wife.'
verses.comment: John references Mosaic law, showing the continuity with the Old Testament ethical standards.

verses.text: So Herodias held a grudge against him and wanted to kill him, but she could not,
verses.comment: Herodias's hostility toward John is reminiscent of other oppositions to God’s messengers (see 1 Kings 19:2; Elijah & Jezebel).

verses.text: because Herod was afraid of John, knowing he was a righteous and holy man, and he protected him. When Herod heard John, he was greatly perplexed, yet he liked to listen to him.
verses.comment: John's holiness is recognized even by a sinful ruler, a sign of the witness provided by righteous living.

verses.text: But an opportune day came, when Herod, on his birthday, gave a banquet for his high officials, military commanders, and the leading men of Galilee.
verses.comment: The lavish setting stands in sharp contrast to John’s imprisonment, highlighting the world's fleeting glory versus true holiness.

verses.text: When Herodias’s daughter came in and danced, she pleased Herod and his guests. The king said to the girl, 'Ask me for whatever you wish, and I will give it to you.'
verses.comment: A sinful promise is made under the influence of earthly pleasure, leading to the martyrdom of a prophet.

verses.text: And he promised her with an oath, 'Whatever you ask me, I will give you, up to half of my kingdom.'
verses.comment: Herod echoes Old Testament royal generosity (see Esther), but acts recklessly.

verses.text: She went out and said to her mother, 'What should I ask for?' She answered, 'The head of John the Baptist.'
verses.comment: Herodias’s consuming hatred leads to John’s execution, the fate of a true prophet.

verses.text: Immediately she hurried to the king with the request, 'I want you to give me, right now, the head of John the Baptist on a platter.'
verses.comment: The immediacy of the request reveals both the manipulation at play and the cost of speaking truth.

verses.text: Though the king was deeply distressed, because of his oaths and his guests, he did not want to refuse her.
verses.comment: Like Jephthah (cf. Judges 11:35), an ill-considered vow leads to tragedy. Herod is a warning about following social pressures over God's law.

verses.text: Immediately the king sent a guard with orders to bring John’s head. He went, beheaded him in the prison,
verses.comment: The cost of prophetic witness: John becomes the forerunner of Christ not just in life, but in martyrdom.

verses.text: brought his head on a platter, and gave it to the girl, who gave it to her mother.
verses.comment: Vile circumstances surround the death of one of God’s holiest men. Suffering and apparent defeat do not prevent the victory of truth.

verses.text: When his disciples heard of it, they came and took his body and laid it in a tomb.
verses.comment: John's disciples give his body honorable burial, foreshadowing the care given to Jesus’ body after His crucifixion (cf. Mark 15:46).

verses.text: The apostles returned to Jesus and reported to Him all that they had done and taught.
verses.comment: The apostles are accountable to Jesus, the head of their mission. This community accountability is a precedent for the visible, structured leadership in the Church.

verses.text: He said to them, 'Come away by yourselves to a secluded place and rest a while.' For many were coming and going, and they did not even have time to eat.
verses.comment: Jesus calls for rest, showing His care. Spiritual and physical renewal are essential for effective ministry (cf. Psalm 23:2).

verses.text: So they went away in the boat by themselves to a solitary place.
verses.comment: Time alone with Jesus prepares the apostles for further ministry. Solitude is often needed even amidst busyness.

verses.text: But many saw them leaving and recognized them, and ran together on foot from all the towns; they arrived ahead of them.
verses.comment: The people’s eagerness demonstrates their hunger for truth and the attraction of Christ.

verses.text: When He came ashore, He saw a great crowd and had compassion on them, because they were like sheep without a shepherd. So He began to teach them many things.
verses.comment: Jesus’ compassion fulfills the hope for a true Shepherd (Ezekiel 34). His teaching is a form of pastoral care, leading to spiritual feeding.

verses.text: When it grew late, His disciples came to Him and said, 'This is a remote place, and it is already very late.'
verses.comment: The setting anticipates a miraculous provision, reminiscent of Israel in the wilderness.

verses.text: 'Send the crowds away so they can go into the surrounding countryside and villages and buy themselves something to eat.'
verses.comment: The disciples' solution is practical, but lacks awareness of Jesus’ power to provide.

verses.text: But He answered them, 'You give them something to eat.' They said, 'Should we go and buy two hundred denarii worth of bread and give it to them to eat?'
verses.comment: Jesus involves the disciples in the miracle, hinting at their future ministry role in providing spiritual food to the people.

verses.text: He said to them, 'How many loaves do you have? Go and see.' When they found out, they said, 'Five, and two fish.'
verses.comment: The small offering prefigures God's ability to do great things with the little we bring — a principle of faith.

verses.text: Then He commanded them all to sit down in groups on the green grass.
verses.comment: Order is established for the miracle, echoing Psalm 23:2: 'He makes me lie down in green pastures.'

verses.text: So they sat down in groups of hundreds and fifties.
verses.comment: Jesus organizes the crowd, recalling Moses organizing Israel. Order in spiritual life and worship is vital for true community.

verses.text: Taking the five loaves and the two fish, He looked up to heaven, blessed and broke the loaves, and gave them to the disciples to set before the people. He also divided the two fish among them all.
verses.comment: Jesus blesses, breaks, and distributes food — prefiguring the Eucharist. He acts as both host and mediator, creating a spiritual meal that feeds the multitude.

verses.text: They all ate and were satisfied.
verses.comment: The satisfaction from the meal signifies God's sufficiency. There is a literal and spiritual fulfillment here: Christ is the true Bread who feeds the people wholly.

verses.text: And they picked up twelve baskets full of broken pieces and of the fish.
verses.comment: The twelve baskets correspond to the twelve apostles and tribes of Israel, a sign that the true community of God will never lack spiritual nourishment.

verses.text: Those who ate the loaves were five thousand men.
verses.comment: The number parallels Moses feeding Israel in the wilderness. The miracle points to Jesus’ greater role in providing spiritual manna (cf. John 6:32).

verses.text: Immediately He made His disciples get into the boat and go ahead of Him to Bethsaida, while He dismissed the crowd.
verses.comment: Jesus remains behind to dismiss the crowds, demonstrating His authority and servant leadership.

verses.text: After saying farewell to them, He went up on the mountain to pray.
verses.comment: Jesus’ prayer reveals His ongoing communion with the Father. The mountain is a biblical symbol of meeting with God (cf. Exodus 19:3; 1 Kings 19:8).

verses.text: When evening came, the boat was in the middle of the sea, and He was alone on the land.
verses.comment: The separation sets the stage for the following revelation of Jesus' divine power.

verses.text: He saw them straining at the oars, because the wind was against them. In the fourth watch of the night He came toward them, walking on the sea. He meant to pass by them,
verses.comment: Jesus walks on water, recalling divine attributes (cf. Job 9:8 — 'He alone treads on the waves'). 'He meant to pass by' alludes to Old Testament theophanies where God reveals Himself (cf. Exodus 33:19-23).

verses.text: but when they saw Him walking on the sea, they thought He was a ghost, and they cried out,
verses.comment: Fear and confusion reveal both human frailty and the mystery of Christ’s person.

verses.text: for they all saw Him and were terrified. But immediately He spoke to them and said, 'Take heart; it is I. Do not be afraid.'
verses.comment: 'It is I' = Greek 'Ego eimi,' the phrase used for God Himself in Exodus 3:14. Jesus is revealing His divinity (cf. John 8:58).

verses.text: Then He got into the boat with them, and the wind stopped. They were utterly astounded,
verses.comment: Jesus' power over nature is again proof that He is more than a prophet — He commands creation itself, a divine prerogative.

verses.text: for they had not understood about the loaves, but their hearts were hardened.
verses.comment: A lack of spiritual insight connects the miracle of the loaves and Jesus’ divine identity. Spiritual understanding grows gradually, often through signs and grace.

verses.text: When they had crossed over, they came to land at Gennesaret and anchored there.
verses.comment: The journey continues to regions hungry for Christ’s ministry.

verses.text: As soon as they got out of the boat, the people immediately recognized Him.
verses.comment: Word about Jesus spreads rapidly — people's receptivity contrasts with the earlier rejection in Nazareth.

verses.text: They ran throughout that whole region and began to carry the sick on mats to wherever they heard He was.
verses.comment: Faith compels action. The people are unashamed to seek healing, a sign of persistent faith.

verses.text: Wherever He entered villages, cities, or the countryside, they laid the sick in the marketplaces and begged Him that they might touch even the fringe of His garment. And as many as touched Him were healed.
verses.comment: Touching the fringe of Jesus' garment (see Numbers 15:38–39) reflects faith in His person. Healing flows from Christ through visible means, illustrating how God uses material things to convey His power and grace.
